Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports planning for the Sanford Center for Science Education (SCSE) which will be the exhibition and education component of the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory (DUSEL) at the former Homestake Gold Mine in Lead, South Dakota. In particular, the award supports the design of what will go into the SCSE -- key program components and a preliminary design of its exhibit space. This request will also support the development of the SCSE's organizational structure and a transition plan for getting from preconstruction through Opening Day. This science education center is planned to provide exceptionally innovative and cutting-edge exhibit experiences, expand educational opportunities for a wide array of students and teachers, and generally enhance the efforts of Homestake-DUSEL.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This 7-year award supported the design and establishment of the Sanford Science Education Center as the education and outreach arm of the Sanford Underground Research Facility (also known as Sanford Lab). The development and dissemination of planning documents, reports, and case studies all represent accomplishments of intellectual merit associated with this award, and all are available through the Center's website. Broader impacts were realized through the implementation of numerous education programs reaching tens of thousands of students, educators, and members of the general public, building understanding about the science and engineering of Sanford Lab and about science and engineering more broadly. Cultural outreach efforts also had broader impact, establishing partnerships and laying a foundation for future collaborations, especially within American Indian communities throughout South Dakota.

 

In late 2010, within the first year of this award, federal oversight of the Sanford Underground Research Facility (formerly known as the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory or DUSEL) shifted from the National Science Foundation to the US Department of Energy. This shift caused significant changes in the development of the Sanford Science Education Center (SSEC). When "Education & Outreach Planning for DUSEL" was originally awarded, a single new education facility was envisioned onsite at the underground laboratory. By 2013 (Year 3 of this award), a new model for the Sanford Science Education Center had emerged that takes advantage of existing physical infrastructure, leverages local and regional partnerships more fully, and capitalizes on educational audiences where they already exist. As of 2014 (Year 4 of this award), the newly envisioned Sanford Science Education Center was formally established.

 

Rather than constructing a single new building to house its complete collection of programs, the Sanford Science Education Center coordinates activities across three complementary facilities. One of the facilities is immediately onsite at Sanford Lab, providing classroom space for hands-on activities with school groups and teachers, videoconferencing capability, and accommodations for conferences. The second is the Sanford Lab Homestake Visitor Center on Main Street in Lead, South Dakota (about a kilometer from Sanford Lab) that serves general public and tourist audiences and also school groups. This visitor center, which celebrated its grand opening in June of 2015 (in Year 5 of this award), features both the science of Sanford Lab and the history of Homestake Mining Company. Visitors learn through touch-screen displays, 3-dimensional models, explanatory panels, and trolley tours that include a stop at the lab. The third facility is a fully renovated Jonas Science Building at Black Hills State University (BHSU), about 30 kilometers from the lab. The Sanford Science Education Center at BHSU celebrated its grand opening in May of 2016 (in Year 6 of this award). It was designed and is outfitted to test innovations in undergraduate science teaching and to support teacher preparation. The building also features Sanford Lab displays, artifacts, windows into research labs, and a touchscreen kiosk featuring Sanford Lab-related videos.

 

This three-site model of the Sanford Science Education Center relies heavily on partnerships. By capitalizing on the strengths of each partner institution and by having three distinct facilities, the Sanford Science Education Center is able to stretch limited fiscal resources and still make a sizeable impact. The SSEC touched over 15,000 K-12 students, undergraduates, and teachers and over 65,000 members of the general public during the seventh and final year of this planning award (2016-17). The host institutions for each facility pay their own general operating and maintenance costs as part of the partnership agreements, and they contribute human resources at each site to complement the core staff of the Center. Furthermore, the three-site model allows for program delivery where audiences exist naturally or have ready access. The Homestake Visitor Center, for example, had a long history of attracting and serving tourists and school groups prior to its transformation into the joint Sanford Lab Homestake Visitor Center. Also, BHSU has the largest undergraduate teacher preparation program in South Dakota.

 

The future of the Sanford Science Education Center is bright. All three facilities are up and running and well outfitted, a core staff of six is in place, and a robust suite of education programs is being delivered across South Dakota and beyond. Base funding mechanisms are in place for the foreseeable future, and the number of students, teachers, and members of the general public that the Center serves is on an upward trajectory.

 

Many thanks to the National Science Foundation for helping to launch this endeavor and for remaining committed throughout its changing circumstances.
